title: Wednesday, 26th July, 2017

11:20 am
BE11:20am

ITV has reported a 12% 1H adjusted EPS beat. There are several
positives that should support the shares today: 1) 2Q NAR of -7.2% was better than the -8% guide/forecasts; 2) The guidance for c.-4% NAR in 3Q confirms our expectation of a positive inflection; 3) Audience share is stable and online video performance strong; 4) S.73 repealed from 31 July paving way for retrans fee discussions; 5) FY guidance has been maintained and our forecasts are unchanged, while the 1H cost beat provides a buffer should ad trends worsen. At 11.3x 2017E P/E we rate ITV Buy rated.

BE11:21am

Revenue vs. Expectations — ITV reported 2Q revenue of £727m, which is 1%/1.5% below Citi/consensus. NAR, however, came in slightly ahead at -7.2% in 2Q vs. Citi/consensus -8% (May better). 1H adjusted EBITA of £403m is 11.5%/8.5% ahead of Citi/consensus and adjusted EPS of 7.7p, 12% ahead. An interim DPS of 2.52p is slightly ahead of consensus 2.4p.
 Focus #1: Improving NAR Trend in 3Q — The guidance for 3Q NAR of c.-4% (July -5%, August -4%, September flat to -5%) confirms our expectation of an inflection in NAR trends (we assumed c.-3% in 3Q). Coupled with commentary that: 1) NAR declines are fairly isolated (food, retail, finance) and; 2) Strong on screen trends (flat SOCI against a Euro Cup comp and 15% increase in ITV2 SOCI for 16- 34 year olds), we expect this to be taken well.
 Focus #2: Studios & Online Video Strength; S.73 Repealed From 31 July – While Studios organic growth was flat in 1H due to the comp of The Voice license sale to China in 1H16, Americas organic growth was up 31% and the pipeline for both scripted and unscripted is strong (the Love Island success may spread beyond the UK next year). The group has secured 85% of the budgeted FY revenue for Studios. Online video advertising is up double digit in 1H, and online video viewing up 34%. ITV notes that S.73 will be repealed from 31 July, paving the way for retransmission fee discussions (with cable).

PM11:21am

Any retread of the bid spec?

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Focus #3: Unchanged Guidance; 1H Cost Beat Provides a Buffer — The notable 1H EBITA beat was driven by programming costs - 3% (guidance had been for flat) and other broadcast costs -11% (£26m lower than us). The group has maintained FY guidance, including the cost savings guidance (£25m programming and £25m non programming savings). The lower 1H costs gives ITV a buffer if advertising trends soften more than expected.

BE11:22am

Haven't heard the bid angle for at least a week.

PM11:22am

11:22 am

BE11:22am

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Drowning in trading statements today

PM11:29am

Most of which are dull

BE11:29am

Yeah, including one overnight from Sage to coincide with it buying something expensive.

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

Sage Group PLC (SGE:LSE): Last: 700.50, up 12.5 (+1.82%), High: 702.50, Low: 685.50, Volume: 5.46m
BE11:30am

Paying $850m for Intacct as a catch-up move towards cloud accountancy.

11:30 am
PM11:31am

(Je Suis Muppet -- sorry. We clearly have an issue with stale pricing.)

PM11:31am

Belated catch-up

BE11:31am

Which is something Sage didn't fancy for a very long time, famously. And now, with figures not terribly impressive, seems to have had a change of heart.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Any paid nearly 10x sales for a loss making business.

BE11:31am

That'll remain loss making for the foreseeable.

BE11:32am

And there's no guidance at this point on what synergies there are, though management's optimistic of finding some.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

And because Sage is late here, it's coming up against the likes of Netsuite (as in Oracle) and Microsoft.

BE11:33am

The fact that Sage put out underwhelming Q3s at the same time seems not to be a coincidence.

BE11:34am

Still ..... Numis likes it. Cautiously.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

An $850m acquisition that is 2% dilutive to Dec-18 PE, 8% dilutive to EV:NOPAT, comes off the back of a weak Q3 (recurring revenue growth c.8.1% vs prior TTM 10.4%), and is 60-100bp dilutive to our margin forecasts (offset by greater revenue thus minimal EBITA impact). Yet we are incrementally more positive. In short the acquisition of US mid-tier Cloud accounting software vendor Intacct adds c.130-150bp to overall growth rates, gives Sage a position of strength in a segment of the US market, and provides a cloud-native mid-tier accounting app that would have been, in our view, almost impossible for Sage to develop organically. We see a possibility that this will prove the kind of acquisition that we look back on as genuinely transformational. Furthermore, to hold overall margins at 27% despite investment implies ex.Intacct/Fairsail margins 29-30%. We raise our target multiple to 25x given the higher growth rate, which yields an 813p TP (was 756p).

BE11:35am

Barclays less impressed.

BE11:35am

Two years into its transformation plan, growth remains below 6% for Sage and, with the £654m acquisition of US cloud accounting vendor Intacct, it appears Sage is indeed moving to Plan B. In the long term this may well be the necessary acceptance that its existing business is simply behind in the cloud, however, in the near term it is another dilutive deal (following the US payments disposal) and it also confirms a change in direction from the transformation plan put in place two years ago. A scenario of slowing growth and two dilutive M&A deals is arguably some way away from the strategy investors bought into at the June 2015 capital markets day.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

... though they've been unimpressed for quite a while. Here's the thesis, in short.

BE11:36am

Sage’s global growth products have simply been too small to drive a meaningful acceleration in organic growth and, with cloud competition increasing across Sage’s addressable market, it has been a substantial challenge to reinvigorate the on-premise core, despite the reinvestment of 500bp of sales from G&A to sales & marketing.
Intacct is a US-only cloud financial management/accounting software vendor, which serves the medium and mid-market segments of the market (competing most often we expect with NetSuite, owned by Oracle). This places it slightly below (but arguably overlapping) with X3 and above the new Sage Live solution. Such a deal is not without risk and the cultural differences between Newcastle and California are substantial, with risk around staff attrition after any lock-up ends.

BE11:37am

Intacct appears a gem of a business, however, it has arguably limited overlap with Sage’s core products and is about new customer acquisition, not migration. It adds more to the growth rate of the business though than all the existing global growth products combined and is already some three times the size of Sage One, the cloud business Sage has grown over the last years into the low end of the market. Retaining talent will be key, something notoriously difficult with cloud acquisitions.
However, it is also an expensive acquisition and still only accounts for 4-5% of Sage’s revenues. In any case, Sage is at the point of delivery in its transformation strategy to accelerate growth and improve margin organically within the business and this has not been delivered. As management noted at the time of the CMD, without significant momentum out of FY17 and into FY18, the transition will not have been a success and we believe investors were not anticipating a dilutive disposal of the US payments business as well as dilutive acquisitions into the cloud as being necessary. While we therefore view the acquisition as likely a positive for the longer term, it does not solve the issue that the remaining 90%+ of Sage’s business that is on-premise could continue to face increasing headwinds. Adjusting for US payments dilution and the dilution of the deal, Sage is currently trading around 23x FY18E P/E or 26x EV/NOPAT – Underweight.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

"the cultural differences between Newcastle and California are substantial" is one of those things that's probably accurate, but doesn't really need pointed out.

PM11:41am

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Post the close of trading yesterday, MTRO announced a placing of new shares representing 9.9% of the issued share capital at a price of 3465p per share. The placing was successfully completed raising total proceeds of c.£278m, which strengthens its CET1 ratio by 590bps (to 19.4% pro forma at 30th June). MTRO has also interim results for the six months to 30th June 2017. In overall terms, MTRO’s results are in line with expectations with H117 net income of £3.1m. MTRO reported a H117 NIM of 1.97% (versus our 2.00% forecast). Q217 NIM of 1.92% was down 10bps on Q117 levels, adversely impacted by higher liquid asset balances (large HTM book raises ringfencing risks). This more than offset a continued reduction in the cost of deposits, which had fallen to 53bps for Q217. MTRO reported strong loan growth in Q217 with net loans (including the recent £600m portfolio acquisition) +20% q/q to £7.8bn, broadly in line with our expectations for £7.9bn at 30th June. Strong deposit growth continued in Q217 with deposit balances +9% q/q to £9.8bn (Goodbody: £9.9bn) at end-H117. MTRO accessed an additional £0.6bn of TFS funding in Q217meaning total TFS drawdowns stood at £1.8bn at end-H117. As a result, MTRO’s LTD increased to 79% at 30th June (from 72% in Q117). MTRO has also notably increased its 2020 LTD target to c.85% from c.80% (we are at 89% at end-FY19 anyway).

PM11:41am

We have consistently noted that MTRO needs to raise CET1 capital and the placing is no surprise to us in that context. Executing the transaction at yesterday’s closing price will be likely welcomed by existing investors (our forecasts assumed a material £500m capital raise in FY18F) –though more capital will be needed in time. Continued positive momentum from a results perspective (despite the delay in 2020 targets) will also be welcomed. We will review our forecasts in light of this new information but we still believe that MTRO’s valuation is demanding.Home...Recommendation: SellClosing Price: £34.65John Cronin

BE11:42am

Okay, so the acceleration in loan growth has required CET1 to get whittled down to 13,5% from 18.1% at the year end 2016.

11:41 am
PM11:42am

SO John Cronin doesnt know why it's trading at 4xNAV either

BE11:42am

I mean, this is what banks are supposed to do. They're supposed to lend money. Rather than, for instance, using it for buybacks.

BE11:43am

However, to accelerate loan growth then have to raise £300m to pad your CET1 back out to a respectable level doesn't look right to me somehow.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Here's Gordon at Investec. He doesn't like it either.

BE11:44am

Based on our robust loan growth assumptions, without a capital raise, Metro Bank’s CET1 capital ratio would have fallen to 9.1% by Q4 2019e. As such, we welcome management’s decision to act now. Metro has raised £277.9bn (gross) via an overnight ABB, placing 8.02m new shares at a price of 3465p, equal to last night’s close.

BE11:44am

The inevitable mathematical consequence of the capital raise is, (necessarily) to dilute/defer Metro Bank’s RoE ambitions. It has moved back its existing 18% RoE target from 2020 to 2022, with a new interim target of 14% in 2020. Our existing 2020 forecast (which already assumed a £0.3bn raise during 2017) is 15%, though we will review this after today’s Q2 results meeting.

EPS improved by 85% QoQ to a (record) 2.5p in Q2 2017. The key driver was loan growth of £1.3bn (+20% QoQ). Deposit growth actually slowed to £0.7bn (+12% QoQ), hence the loans:deposit ratio rose from 72% to 79%. Metro Bank now targets an 85% L/D ratio by 2020 (previously 80%), which we welcome.

NIM declined 0.1% QoQ to 1.92% in Q2 2017 reflecting excess liquidity ahead of the £0.6bn portfolio acquisition. As such, this will prove transitory, though we still struggle to reconcile Metro’s 3% 2020 target for Adjusted NIM (INVe 2.61%).

Positive YoY “jaws” of 49% vs 30% were maintained, albeit narrower than we expected. For now, on 3.9x 2016 tNAV, we continue to regard valuation as full.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

BE11:54am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: GSK reported 2Q17 sales of £7,320m (+1% vs cons), adj. operating profit of £2,083m (+2.3% vs cons), adj. EPS of 27.20p (+3.4% vs cons). Sales surprise seems to drop through to EBIT.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Company reported 2Q17 sales of £848m for Advair (+1.3% vs cons), £988m for their dolutegravir franchise (Tivicay & Triumeq, +6.7% vs cons), and £1,111m for Vaccines (+2.9% vs cons). Consumer was weaker than expected (-2% v cons).

BE11:54am

GSK previously guided for 5-7% adjusted EPS growth (with no US Advair generics),
now lowered to 3-5% reflecting the impact of a Priority Review voucher and investments. Long term guidance remains unchanged despite incremental savings.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: We expect stock to react negatively given the lack of change to long-term guidance despite incremental savings suggests tougher underlying trends.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

There's a slew of other stuff around GSK with regards Gilead's HIV treatment

BE11:55am

And safety data published at the IAS conference

BE11:56am

Quick line from Berenberg to summarise where that stands.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Tide may be turning sooner than expected for two-drug regimens:
Physicians have been sceptical about the potential for two-drug regimens in the past, citing a need to demonstrate how they can benefit the patient. However, ViiV notes two interesting facts: 1) French guidelines have been updated to include a two-drug regimen recommendation for some
patients; and 2) two-drug regimens are already used in a minority of
patients in Italy and Spain (c10%). The US, UK and Germany lag behind on c3% and will require more work to initiate change. We have not changed our forecasts and think triples will continue to dominate but are watching the accumulating evidence for two-drug regimens with interest.

BE11:57am

Data for the most promising of ViiV’s two-drug regimens looks good: A combination of dolutegravir and lamivudine showed good efficacy in the early-stage ACTG A5353 trial and we anticipate hopes rising for the phase III GEMINI studies that read out in H1 next year. The LATTE-2 trial showed that efficacy for an injectable formulation of cabotegravir (another integrase inhibitor) and J&J’s rilpivirine is also strong and could offer a novel option for those wanting to avoid being reminded that they are sick by the act of daily pill-taking.

BE11:57am

Actually, that's getting hardcore noodly. Let's push on.
